title: Prepare Marinade

transcript_segments.text: Assalamu Alaikum, I'm Chef Afzal and today I'm going to share with you the recipe for Sindhi Biryani. Friends, this is a delicious biryani you can make at home for parties.

I believe this biryani is easier to make than other Karachi-style biryanis, and InshaAllah it will be delicious too. It's a very simple recipe, and whenever you make it for a party, everyone will enjoy it. So without wasting time, let’s start this amazing recipe.

Bismillah ir-Rahman ir-Rahim. Friends, Sindhi Biryani is traditionally made with sela rice, but I know my viewers use basmati rice. So in this video, I'm using basmati rice. I’ve taken 3 glasses, which weigh around 1 kg. I’ll tell you later how many people this serves. First, let's wash the rice.

instruction: Add the mutton or chicken pieces to the marinade. Mix well and let it rest for at least 1-2 hours in the refrigerator.
title: Marinate the Meat

transcript_segments.text: We’ll wash the rice twice gently by rubbing it lightly. Then we’ll soak it for an hour. Meanwhile, I’ve taken a pressure cooker. I have 1.5 kg of meat with some fat. I’m adding 3 tomatoes to it.

instruction: Peel and cut potatoes in halves. Rinse and pat them dry.
title: Prepare Potatoes

transcript_segments.text: We’ll wash the rice twice gently by rubbing it lightly. Then we’ll soak it for an hour. Meanwhile, I’ve taken a pressure cooker. I have 1.5 kg of meat with some fat. I’m adding 3 tomatoes to it.

instruction: Heat oil in a deep pan and fry the potato halves until golden brown. Remove and set aside.
title: Fry Potatoes

transcript_segments.text: We’ll wash the rice twice gently by rubbing it lightly. Then we’ll soak it for an hour. Meanwhile, I’ve taken a pressure cooker. I have 1.5 kg of meat with some fat. I’m adding 3 tomatoes to it.

instruction: In a large pot, heat oil. Add cumin seeds, black peppercorns, cloves, cardamoms, cinnamon, and bay leaf. Fry for 30-40 seconds until fragrant.
title: Heat Oil and Fry Whole Spices

transcript_segments.text: Now add 1.5 tablespoons of red chili powder and 1.5 tablespoons of salt. The salt in biryani should be slightly more than usual so that it tastes right in the final dish. Then I added 1 tablespoon of cumin seeds.
Add ½ tablespoon turmeric, ¼ tablespoon nutmeg and mace powder, 1 small spoon whole cumin seeds, 1 broken piece of star anise, 8–10 cloves, 5 green cardamoms, and 1 small spoon black peppercorns.
Add two pieces of cinnamon, 3 bay leaves, and 1 cup of yogurt. Add 1.5 tablespoons of green chili paste. If you're using whole chilies, grind about 5.

Add 2.5 tablespoons of ginger-garlic paste. Use a generous amount of this paste. Then add two glasses of water. Since we’ll cook in a pressure cooker for 25–28 minutes, I’m using a little extra water. We'll reduce it later.

instruction: Add sliced onions to the pot. Fry them on medium heat until deep golden brown, stirring occasionally.
title: Add and Fry Onions

transcript_segments.text: Now I’ve closed the pressure cooker and placed it on the stove for 25 minutes—first 5–6 minutes on high, then on medium flame. Meanwhile, on another burner, we’ll fry onions. I took 1 cup oil and sliced two medium onions for frying.

instruction: Add chopped tomatoes to the browned onions. Cook until the tomatoes are soft and the mixture thickens.
title: Cook Tomatoes

transcript_segments.text: Now I’ve closed the pressure cooker and placed it on the stove for 25 minutes—first 5–6 minutes on high, then on medium flame. Meanwhile, on another burner, we’ll fry onions. I took 1 cup oil and sliced two medium onions for frying.

instruction: Add the marinated meat along with all the marinade to the pot. Stir well to combine with the onion-tomato base.
title: Add Marinated Meat

transcript_segments.text: As you can see, the onions are nicely fried. Save the oil; we’ll need it later in the biryani. First, remove the fried onions from the pot and then strain and store the leftover oil separately. The pressure cooker has finished as well—here’s a look at the meat—it’s perfectly cooked.

I cooked it for about 25 minutes, and the meat is now tender. We’ll use the same pot where we fried the onions to finish cooking the biryani. Let’s dry the curry a bit and sauté it to reduce the water. We'll also add some ingredients during this time.

instruction: Cover and cook the meat on medium heat until tender and oil separates from the masala. Add water as needed during cooking.
title: Cook Meat Until Tender

transcript_segments.text: I cooked it for about 25 minutes, and the meat is now tender. We’ll use the same pot where we fried the onions to finish cooking the biryani. Let’s dry the curry a bit and sauté it to reduce the water. We'll also add some ingredients during this time.

instruction: Mix in coriander powder and garam masala powder. Cook for a few more minutes to deepen the flavor.
title: Add Powdered Spices

transcript_segments.text: Add 7–8 dried plums and around 8–10 prunes. These are essential in Sindhi biryani. Add ½ tablespoon of Chinese salt (MSG)—most popular biryanis use it for better flavor. Also add kewra water (screwpine essence).
Without kewra water, biryani lacks its signature aroma. Add 3 tablespoons of it, and sauté everything well. We’ll dry this curry mixture over the next 5–7 minutes until the water evaporates.
Now we'll add water for cooking the rice. (Note: line repeated for emphasis.) The idea is to add water based on rice quantity.

instruction: Add the fried potatoes, chopped mint leaves, coriander leaves, and slit green chilies. Stir gently to blend.
title: Add Fried Potatoes and Herbs

transcript_segments.text: Now we'll add water for cooking the rice. (Note: line repeated for emphasis.) The idea is to add water based on rice quantity.

instruction: Rinse the basmati rice in water 2-3 times. Soak in water for 30 minutes, then drain.
title: Rinse and Soak Rice

transcript_segments.text: For premium basmati rice, 4.5 glasses of water should be enough to keep the biryani fluffy. Let it boil on high heat, then add the soaked rice. Keep the flame high initially, then lower it to allow the rice to expand.

We haven’t added oil yet because the meat itself was fatty. If you’re using lean meat, then add 1 cup of cooking oil while making the curry. Now after 4–5 minutes on low flame, most of the water is absorbed by the rice.
Now gently shake the pot—don’t stir too much with a spoon because basmati rice breaks easily. I’m adding about ½ tablespoon of yellow food color at this stage.

instruction: Bring a large pot of water to a boil. Add salt generously.
title: Boil Water for Rice

transcript_segments.text: Now gently shake the pot—don’t stir too much with a spoon because basmati rice breaks easily. I’m adding about ½ tablespoon of yellow food color at this stage.

instruction: Add soaked rice to boiling water. Cook until 70-80% done. Drain and keep aside.
title: Cook Rice Partially

transcript_segments.text: Add food color when there’s still a bit of water left in the rice. Also, I’m adding ½ cup of the previously saved fried onion oil. It enhances flavor and prevents the rice from sticking. Finally, sprinkle the fried onions over the top.

Now it’s time to let it steam (dum). Place a pan (tawa) under the pot, and let it cook for 12–15 minutes. Always note the time when doing dum so the rice doesn’t overcook. I’ll leave it for 15 minutes and then show you the final result.

instruction: In a large heavy-bottomed pot, spread half of the cooked rice at the bottom.
